explanation: The report is not correct. In the function qmark (the location of '?') is turned into a NUL before the unescape callback is invoked (*qmark = '\0'), and uri is NUL-terminated at the original uri_len (uri[uri_len] = '\0'). Thus the unescape callback is only supposed to operate on the NUL-terminated path portion (it is passed uri), and it will not touch or move the bytes that make up the query segment (the bytes after the original '?') or the terminating NUL that was placed at the original uri_len. Consequently qmark and qmark+1 still point inside the original buffer and the query substring remains NUL-terminated; subsequent uses of strchr, memcmp, etc. will not necessarily read past the bounds of the underlying object. The only way the reported out‑of‑bounds scenario could occur is if the unescape_callback violates its implied contract (i.e. it reads or writes beyond the NUL it is given). That would be a bug in the callback implementation, not in the shown code. Therefore the claimed MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 violation of check_uri_match is not valid.
